questions.question: When is it safe to use `--force-with-lease`?
options: Only on main branch
Always, it's completely safe
Never, it's too dangerous
Only on feature branches, never on main
questions.explanation: `--force-with-lease` is safe to use on feature branches after amending or rebasing. Never force push to `main` - it can overwrite important commits and cause problems for your team.

questions.question: When is a good time to commit?
options: Only at the end of the day
When code is broken but you want to save it
Every 5 minutes to save your work
When you've completed a logical piece of work, code compiles, and tests pass
questions.explanation: Commit when you've completed a logical piece of work (e.g., 'Add tests for login endpoint'), code compiles, and tests pass. Each commit should represent a working state.

questions.question: What is rebase and why is it required before merging a PR?
options: Rebase deletes all your commits
Rebase is optional and not recommended
Rebase creates a merge commit
Rebase rewrites commit history by replaying your commits on top of the latest main, creating a clean linear history
questions.explanation: Rebase rewrites commit history by replaying your commits on top of the latest `main`. It creates a clean, linear history without merge commits. All PRs must be rebased before merging.

questions.question: What is the team fork structure in Phase 1?
options: Each team member has their own fork
One team member forks the repo, all members are collaborators on that fork, everyone works from the same fork
Everyone works directly on the main repository
Teams don't use forks
questions.explanation: In Phase 1, one team member forks the starter repository, all team members are added as collaborators on that fork, and everyone clones and pushes to the same fork. This ensures all team members can see each other's work.

questions.question: What should you do if you have too many small 'save point' commits?
options: Delete the branch and start over
Push them all as-is
Create a new branch
Use interactive rebase (`git rebase -i HEAD~N`) to squash them into logical commits
questions.explanation: Use interactive rebase to clean up your commit history. Change `pick` to `squash` for commits you want to combine. This creates a clean history that tells a good story.

questions.question: What is the rule about committing directly to `main`?
options: Never commit directly to main - always create a feature branch first
You can commit directly to main if it's a small change
Main is for experimental code only
Only commit to main on weekends
questions.explanation: Never commit directly to `main`. Always create a feature branch for each feature/assignment. This keeps work isolated and makes code reviews easier.

questions.question: What command should you use to fix a mistake in your last commit?
options: `git revert`
`git commit --fix`
`git commit --amend` - to update the last commit without creating a new one
`git undo`
questions.explanation: Use `git commit --amend` to update the last commit. This is useful when you realize the last commit has a bug or is incomplete. Use `--no-edit` to keep the same message, or `-m` to change it.
